results.title: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
results.brief_description: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.

results.title: Loch Ladies
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This film showcases the many women who drive business in the small Loch Village. The four women featured are representative of the many others who are involved in running businesses in the main street of Loch. These women are smart, funny, hard working and driven individuals who have turned their passion into profit.

results.title: Community banking Bass Coast
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Early in 2001, the banks pulled out of the small coastal town of San Remo in south eastern Victoria, leaving the community with a challenge. Rather than sit on his hands and accept the inevitable consequences of downsizing, a local hardware store owner, Terry Ashenden, pulled together a committee of residents and business owners to overcome the problem.

results.title: ACMI in the Regions: Remembering Culgoa Primary School
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Meagher and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Culgoa Primary School closed its doors for the last time in December 2008, after over 100 years of service, due to the low student intake for the coming year. This film captures moments from a reunion organised to bring together students and teachers in celebration of times past. The town and its people are evidence of the strength and fragility of modern day living in small rural towns. The real, everyday struggles that farmers face and the heartbreaking decisions that families make, whether to stay and “tough it out” or move to a larger satellite town.

results.title: Fight for Country
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description: In 1998, over 5,000 people travelled to Kakadu, in the Northern Territory, to stand alongside the traditional owners of the land, the Mirrar people, and lend their support to the Jabiluka Campaign. The fight to prevent the development of the Jabiluka uranium mine was one of the biggest protest movements in Australia’s history and over 600 people were arrested in the process. It took film-maker Pip Starr four years to make this film, including one year spent documenting these historic events.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions

results.title: The Pizzini Family
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Matt Blackwood, ACMI Content Development, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description: This is a story about an Italian-Australian family made unique by three generations of winemakers and master chefs. Meet Natalie, Alfred, Arnold, Katrina, Carla and matriarch Rosetta Pizzini, hear about the four brothers that immigrated to Australia and started farming tobacco, eventually diversifying to growing Italian variety grapes. The Pizzini’s make their own wine, run a cooking school and manage a boutique hotel in Whitfield, but still the most important part of their day is when they sit together and share a meal, a glass of wine and a laugh.

results.title: Gil and Liz Hopkins
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Gil and Liz Hopkins have lived in Laharum, in western Victoria, for over 30 years. They raised three children there, built their own home, which is nearly completely self-sufficient, with solar panels and reclaimed water. Their hope is to leave the land in better shape than they found it and they’re taking their knowledge to the community to help others do the same.

results.title: 125th anniversary of Tolmie Sports: Feb 2011
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Tolmie Sports is a celebration of community and High Country Heritage. A yearly event, it draws people from far and wide to the tiny town of Tolmie in north-eastern Victoria, to revel in events such as the Wood Chop, Equestrian Sports, and the epic and highly elaborate Three Man Race. “Old-Timers” Mick, Don and Sheila reflect on the history of the event, and some of its more colourful days. 2011 marked the 125th anniversary of the sports, and Tolmie Sports Committee Vice President explains some of the planning that goes into an event of its kind.

results.title: Remembering the past and looking forward to the future
results.creator_credit: Cuong Manh Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A story of escape by boat from Vietnam to a Malaysian refugee camp, and then to Australia in 1986 where Cuong Manh Pham eventually made a new life, reuniting with his family in 1990.
